text: Aleph null (also aleph naught or aleph 0) is the smallest infinite number. It is the cardinality (size) of the set of natural numbers (there are aleph null natural numbers). Georg Cantor invented and named the concept. The symbol for aleph null is \aleph_0. It is the first infinite number in a series of infinite cardinal numbers. In fact, it is the size of any set which can be matched one-to-one with the natural numbers. The set of algebraic numbers, for example, has cardinality \aleph_0. a very easy way to think of it is at the "end" of a number line that holds all natural numbers and this is the infinity that most people think of as infinity. Aleph null is followed by aleph one, an infinite number represented by the symbol \aleph_1. == References == Category:Mathematics Category:Cardinal numbers
title: Aleph null
